response.answer_text: Technically speaking, there are eight former U.S. Presidents who were not born in the United States. George Washington, John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, James Monroe, John Q. Adams, Andrew Jackson, and William Henry Harrison were all born prior to 1776, and therefore were born in British colonies. Martin Van Buren, the 8th President, was the first to be born in the United States. Harrison succeeded him, but every President since John Tyler (the 10th) was born in the U.S. As for someone being born outside the country and becoming President in the future, that hasn’t happened yet, but it probably will at some point. John McCain was actually born in the Panama Canal Zone when it was controlled by the United States. An official ruling was made in his case that he was eligible when he received the GOP nomination in 2000, but this was pretty much academic. Both McCain’s father and grandfather were Admirals in the U.S. Navy. No one in their right mind would have ever interpreted the Constitution as prohibiting the child of a member of the U.S. Armed Forces serving overseas as ineligible for any public office. George Romney was born in Mexico, but both of his parents were U.S. citizens, and he was therefore a U.S. citizen at birth regardless of where he was born. One possibility is Tulsi Gabbard, the U.S. Senator from Hawaii who is an up-and-comer in the Democratic Party. Gabbard was born in American Samoa, but is a natural-born U.S. citizen through her mother, and has lived in Hawaii since she was two.

upvoters.user_id: Rt Rev Pagan Archbishop John Seeley

response.answer_text: Because there were no “natural born citizens” older than 12 or 13 years old at the time the Constitution was ratified, in order to be able to go ahead and elect presidents, the Framers included the “grandfather clause” in the Constitution (“…or a citizen of the United States, at the time of the adoption of this Constitution…”), to exempt the first few from having to be natural born citizens. Eight of the first nine presidents had to be “grandfathered in”, but after that, ALL presidents have had to be born on U.S. soil to parents who were themselves, citizens and then, the “grandfather clause” was no longer necessary. The only exceptions to “birth on U.S. soil to citizen parents” were Chester A. Arthur, who was vice president to Pres. Garfield, who was assassinated, and Arthur was sworn in as president. There was controversy at the time, because Arthur’s father, born in Ireland, had not yet become a naturalized U.S. citizen when Chester was born, and didn’t until Chester was 14 years old. The other “president” who was born on U.S. soil but didn’t have parents who were both citizens, was Barack Obama, whose Kenyan, British subject father was never a citizen or even a legal resident of the U.S., but both men HID their family records and it could not be proven that they were constitutionally ineligible. Arthur had burned his family records to hide the fact that his father wasn’t a citizen at the time Chester was born. Birth on U.S. soil + citizen father + citizen mother = natural born citizen! "Although those Americans who acquire their citizenship under statutes conferring citizenship on the foreign-born children of citizens are not popularly thought of as naturalized citizens, the use of the word "naturalize"in this way has a considerable constitutional history. Congress is empowered by the Constitution to "establish an uniform Rule of Naturalization," Art. I, § 8. Anyone acquiring citizenship solely under the exercise of this power is, constitutionally speaking, a naturalized citizen."-Rogers v. Bellei, 401 U.S. 815 (1971) Rogers v Bellei refers to people like George Romney, Cruz, McCain and yes, Tulsi Gabbard, who were born OUT of the U.S. to one or two citizen parents. They ARE “citizens”, but they are “naturalized by congressional statute” citizens, not natural born citizens and not constitutionally eligible for the presidency or vice presidency.

Too many people have no idea why the Constitution mandates that The President be born to parents (both) who are US Citizens on the day of that birth. Natural Born Citizenship was defined to the Founding Fathers within the text of the only existing Law Book that they had access to. Vattel’s “Law of Nations.” Within that book it said that someone born in a nation to citizen parents had no family ties to any Foreign Nation; a Natural Born Citizen. We had just evicted the British from our new Nation and John Jay, who later became the first Supreme Court Justice, wrote Article Two, part of which required the President to be natural born. But, of course, no one had yet been born in the USA. So, they wrote in a grandfather clause allowing existing citizens an exception. “No Person except a natural born Citizen, or a Citizen of the United States, at the time of the Adoption of this Constitution, shall be eligible to the Office of President; neither shall any Person be eligible to that Office who shall not have attained to the Age of thirty five Years, and been fourteen Years a Resident within the United States.” Now that there are no more original citizens this clause requires that your parents be US citizens when you are born. You also must be 35 years old. The fourteen year resident requirement is no longer an issue because that mandate only assured another citizen of Britain could not arrive on the continent and run for President. Sorry to be the bearer of bad news to many, but just as a newborn inherits their Family Name from the Father, they also inherit the Father’s nationality. When the Constitution was written a woman also inherited the nationality of her new husband, so in it’s original intent the mother’s nationality does not matter as regards holding Office as President.

The constitution says “No Person except a natural born Citizen, or a Citizen of the United States and being 35 years of age or more can be President”. That tells me you can be born in another country, like I was, but naturalized by your parents, who were citizens of the U.S. although in another country when they gave birth. The “or” tells me you only have to be a Citizen of the U.S., doesn’t say you can’t be President if your were born in another country and became a citizen through immigration. I could be wrong, but it seems that what the constitution outlines. I did hear from other people that you cannot be President if you were an immigrant from another country and became a U.S. Citizen, but the wording says otherwise to me. S A group of people claim Obama was not born in the U.S. therefore illegitimate based on his Hawaii birth certificate being proven a forgery by some 3rd party investigative source and based on other records, however, the evidence was not officially investigated by the U.S. government and Obama is officially assumed to be born in Hawaii. However, according to the wording of the constitution, it really didn’t seem to matter either way, because he was a citizen. In addition, there were certainly Presidents that were not born in the U.S.; George Washington, because the U.S. didn’t exist when he was born, along with the first few Presidents after him for the same reason.

“No Person except a natural born Citizen, or a Citizen of the United States, at the time of the Adoption of this Constitution, shall be eligible to the Office of President.”—From Article 2 of the Constitution. With the exception of eight of the first nine U.S. presidents, all of whom were born in what would become states of the U.S. but who by definition couldn’t have been born in a nation that had not yet been born, all presidents have come within the “natural-born” citizenship requirement. The governing interpretation of that apparently focuses upon the citizenship-status of a candidate’s parent or parents. Several major candidates for presidents were born to American citizen parents but outside one of the American states and, if they had won election, would have been eligible for inauguration. Barry Goldwater, the Republican nominee in 1964, was born in Arizona, but before it was elevated from the status of territory to that of a state. John McCain, nominated by the GOP in 2008, had American parents but he was born in the Panama Canal Zone (then under U.S. jurisdiction, but now a part of the nation of Panama). Ted Cruz, a major candidate for nomination in 2016, had America parents but was born in Canada. One thing for sure: the claim of “Birthers” notwithstanding: Hawaii was a state of the United States when Barack Obama was born there in 1961.

Article II Section 1 Clause 5 of the Constitution states: No Person except a natural born Citizen, or a Citizen of the United States, at the time of the Adoption of this Constitution, shall be eligible to the Office of President;neither shall any Person be eligible to that Office who shall not have attained to the Age of thirty five Years, andBeen fourteen Years a Resident within the United States.No one has ever become president that did not qualify under Article II. Natural Born Citizen = someone who was a U.S. citizen at birth with no need to go through a naturalization proceeding at some later time.(http://harvardlawreview.org/2015/03/on-the-meaning-of-natural-born-citizen/ and / or Natural born citizen) FYI: Mitt Romney was born in Detroit, MI in 1947, even if his parents were from Mars he is a natural born citizen.Ted Cruz, born Calgary, Canada was born to American citizens, which makes him a citizen too.

The presidents born before the singing of the Declaration of Independence obviously couldn't have been born in the US, but they were born in the land that would become the US. The US requires that a President be a natural born US citizen. This does not preclude them being born outside the US if their parents were American citizens. We have several examples of candidates who were born outside the US running. George Romney, father of Mitt Romney ran for President, but he was born in Mexico American parents. John McCain was born in Panama, to American parents but was born in an area that the US controlled anyway at the time. We also have Ted Cruz who was born in Canada and he caused a lot of stir because while his mother was indisputably American, his father is Cuban. Now let’s get on to the birther allegations. Most people by now know of the Obama birther theories, that he was actually born in Kenya. His father we know was, but his mother was an American citizen. He was actually not in fact the first president to have such an allegation. It was claimed during his time that Chester Arthur was secretly born in Canada. That too has been officially debunked.

No President was ever born outside of the United States. There have been conspiracies, however. The Obama-Kenya conspiracy is one of the more famous ones, since it took place in modern times (and is still an ongoing debate among conspiracy theorists). There are romours that Chester Arthur was born in Canada. Although he was born in Vermont, conspiracists reason that he was actually born in Canada, but was given US Citizenship because he lived in a village right on the border. Finally, every President before Martin Van Buren was born before 1776, when the United States was territory of Great Britain. However, they still qualified to become President of the United States, since they were born on the soil of the Americas. George WashingtonJohn AdamsThomas JeffersonJames MadisonJames MonroeJohn Quincy AdamsAndrew Jackson I hope I helped!

If by “America”, you mean the United States of America, then George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, John Adams, James Madison, James Monroe, John Quincy Adams, Andrew Jackson, Martin Van Buren, William Henry Harrison, and Zachary Taylor were all born before the United States existed. The U.S. Constitution was not ratified until 1789, and all of those presidents were born before 1789. Arguably, one could use the date of 1776 as the cut-off, when the American colonies declared themselves independent of British rule, but the Declaration of Independence did not create the “United States of America”. The Constitution did that, in 1789. There have been no other presidents that were not born within the United States. The Constitution requires the president to be a “natural born citizen” of the U.S., and everyone knows the hubbub that was generated about whether Barack Obama was born in the U.S.

Thank you John for being Knowledgeable of the Constitution! Not too many people would know this. I was also in the US Military for 22 years and have a son that was born abroad, . when he went to work with a Major US Company - they did not even know this. They wanted to see his “Green Card”? My son in law was born in Puerto Rico and the US Government hired him and asked for his Naturalization Papers? This is a shame that a person that was born elsewhere knows more than the US Government on this fact! Puerto Rico is a US Possession and in that, makes anyone from Puerto Rico a US Citizen - DUH! And anyone that is born abroad of a US Citizen - IS A US CITIZEN! I don’t think anyone would join the Military or US Government and have a child abroad, if this was not a fact! What about FBI, US Embassy Duty, CIA and other agencies that go abroad that are allowed to bring their family - I don’t think people would enter those Jobs if their offspring would not be considered a US CITIZEN that was born abroad!!

Many were not BORN in the USA. None of the founding fathers were. They were all born on British soil. Martin Van Buren, our 8th president, was the first President born an American Citizen. Several were born as dual citizens while their parents were visiting in foreign countries. Some of our best known presidents statyed out with dual or multiple citizenship. This is why all presidents have to renounce the citizenship of another country and with the election of Van Buren, has to be an American citizen who has never renounced their American citizenship. There was a great fear dual or multiple citizenships would either produce a “Manchurian candidate” or a conflict of interest in trade, treaty, and military conflict. Justifiable concerns for any country with an elected leader.

The first seven Presidents (Washington, Adams, Jefferson, Madison, Monroe, Adams, Jackson) were not born in the United States. They were born in the English Colonies. The first president born in the US was Martin Van Buren.

The Constitution exempted from the “natural born” requirement those who were citizens of the United States at the time the Constitution was adopted. So someone such Alexander Hamilton, who was born in West Indies, could have become President. But of course he never did and that exemption long ago became irrelevant. Had John McCain succeeded in his presidential bid there might well have been a test court case that would have established a definite interpretation of what the Constitution means by “natural born.” Should Ted Cruz be elected at some point the matter will almost certainly arise then and will, equally certainly, I would think, go to the Supreme Court for a definitive ruling. But that has to await an actual case.

Every single US president up to this point has been born in the United States or in the colonies that eventually became the United States (if they were born before the Constitution was written). People who aren’t born in the United States are allowed to become president as long as their parents are American citizens, but this hasn’t happened yet. People who were born before the Constitution was written were given exemptions to be allowed to run for president as long as they were citizens when the Constitution was signed.

George Washington immediately springs to mind, followed by John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, James Monroe, John Quincy Adams, Andrew Jackson, and William Henry Harrison (all born before the declaration of independence, and were grandfathered in). Barring that bit of trivia, zero presidents have been born outside of the US. Only 8 have been born west of the Mississippi. Only two were born west of the rocky mountains.

Which US presidents were not born in the United States? Any POTUS or individual born prior to 1776 — or more properly, prior to 29 May 1790, when Rhode Island became the final colony/state to ratify the Constitution — was not born in the United States. Thus, since two were born around that date, 9 and possibly 11 were not born in the United States. All others were, and based on the Constitution, all future ones will be — though we might well have one who was born a citizen within in a Territory.

Which US presidents were not born in the United States? Technically that could be many as many were born before our country was known as United States. But the only one I know was born on a Caribbean island in 1750’s on the Island Of Nevis in the town of Charlestown, was Alexander Hamilton. At the time it was a British protectorate. Only in 1983 did Nevis gain its independence from UK.

Technically speaking, there are eight former U.S. Presidents who were not born in the United States. George Washington, John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, James Monroe, John Q. Adams, Andrew Jackson, and William Henry Harrison were all born prior to 1776, and therefore were born in British colonies.

Since the term in the Constitution reads, “natural born citizen”, anyone who was a citizen by virtue of their birth is qualified. You have to have been a resident for 14 years and 35 years old, but those are not open to interpretation. Even if Barack Obama was born in Kenya, since his mother was a citizen, he was eligible to be President. That’s the thing that “birthers” didn’t seem to realize.

Semantically speaking, James K. Polk was the 1st United States President born in the United States of America (U.S.A.) since he was born in 1795 after the Treaty of Paris (1783) where Great Britain recognized U.S.A. as country, and officially ratified in 1784. Up until then, U.S.A. were colonies declaring their independence from their mother country. All the other presidents were born in the colonies before the United States was officially recognized as a country. It is popular to believe that 1776 was the birth of the United States of America, when Thomas Jefferson wrote the Declaration of Independence; however, U.S.A. was not recognized as an independent, sovereign country until after the Revolutionary War (1775–1783) and the defeat of its mother country.

While the conventional answer to who was the first president born in the United States has been Martin Van Buren, there’s a hitch. Van Buren was born in 1782. The United States did not finalize our divorce from England until 1783 with the Treaty of Paris, which in turn was ratified by Congress in 1784. So in the strictest sense of the question, the first American-born president was John Tyler, not Van Buren.

All of those born before the First Continental Congress, which was the first government of the US. It was followed by a second government, the Second Continental Congress and a third government under the Articles of Confederation. Our present government dates from when the Constitution was ratified.
Washington, J. Adams, T. Jefferson, J.Q. Adams, Andrew Jackson, and William H. Harrison were all born prior to 1776, and therefore were born in British colonies.

Probably not, but there is another class of people who are eligible to the office of president: citizens of the United States at the time of the adoption of the Constitution (Article II, Section 1, Clause 5). One of the early presidents might have qualified under this definition.
